ORDER that the Motion for Preliminary Injunction (Doc. 2 ) is GRANTED in part and DENIED in part. FURTHER ORDERED that the City, its agents and employees, are preliminarily enjoined from doing any of the following: 1) Enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans against individuals who practically cannot obtain shelter as long as there are more unsheltered individuals in Phoenix than there are shelter beds available; 2) Seizing any property of the unsheltered without providing prior notice at the property's location that the property will be seized, unless the agent or employee has an objectively reasonable belief that it is (a) abandoned, (b) presents an immediate threat to public health or safety, or (c) is evidence of a crime or contraband; and 3) Absent an immediate threat to public health or safety, destroying said property without maintaining it in a secure location for a period of less than 30 days. FURTHER ORDERED that if property is seized pursuant to a belief that it was abandoned or after the City provides notice that it intends to seize the property, the City, its agents and employees, are further required to provide a notice at the location from which the property was seized, calculated to be readily seen by any owner of the property, describing how and where to retrieve the property and the deadline for retrieving it. case_data.name: Fund for Empowerment v. City of Phoenix
case_data.plaintiff_description: A Phoenix, AZ nonprofit and nine involuntarily unhoused individuals who experienced the destruction of personal property in raids conducted by city law enforcement and/or received criminal citations from police for sleeping and camping in public.

related_cases.name: Blake v. City of Grants Pass

case_data.summary:
This is a challenge to Phoenix’s policies policing homelessness and the City’s treatment of unsheltered individuals concerning unreasonable seizure and destruction of property during “homeless sweeps.” On November 30, 2023, the Fund for Empowerment (FFE) and two individual plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District court for the District of Arizona. Defendants included the City of Phoenix and police officials in their official capacities. Represented by the ACLU of Arizona, plaintiffs sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Monell for violations of their civil rights under the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments. Plaintiffs sought declaratory relief against city codes banning unsheltered people from sleeping in public places, an injunction against the City’s raids on homeless encampments, and attorney’s fees. Plaintiffs claimed that the defendants discriminated against the unsheltered community of Phoenix in various ways as follows:

First, plaintiffs alleged their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights, the latter under the Due Process Clause, were violated during the City’s campaign of “clean sweep” raids targeting the unsheltered community. During such raids, the defendants indiscriminately seized and destroyed personal property of unsheltered individuals without cause, warrant, or due process. Plaintiffs further asserted that defendants’ actions violated plaintiffs’ Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Due Process Clause by forcing the unsheltered community into danger in “the Zone,” an over-crowded downtown city area that is unshaded and reaches temperatures as high as 118’F. Additionally, the plaintiffs asserted in their Eighth Amendment claim that such raids criminalize and punish the population based on their status as unsheltered, while knowing that the city lacks proper affordable housing and emergency shelter to serve as alternative relief. Finally, they asserted in a Monell claim that the defendants knowingly used city ordinances § 23-30(A) (“Camping Ban”) and § 23-48.01 (“Sleeping Ban”) to penalize residents for engaging in unavoidable human activities like sleeping in public while unhoused. The case was originally assigned to District Judge John J. Tuchi and re-assigned to District Judge G. Murray Snow on December 16, 2023. A month after filing the initial complaint, the plaintiffs submitted an amended complaint on January 13, 2023, adding another individual plaintiff to the suit. 

On the same day as filing their complaint, the plaintiffs also filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction, requesting that the court enjoin the City from beginning “enhanced sweeps” of the Zone. On December 16, 2022, the court granted and denied the motion in part. 646 F. Supp. 3d 1117. The judge enjoined the City from seizing and destroying any property of unsheltered individuals without providing prior notice, or securely maintaining it for a minimum of 30 days, because the Fourth Amendment’s Due Process Clause prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures. The judge also enjoined the City from enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans because the Eighth Amendment prohibits the state from imposing criminal penalties for conduct on public property that is an unavoidable consequence of being homeless. However, the judge declined to enjoin the City from moving forward with its new enhanced cleanups of the Zone, because plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the City intends to execute this plan by unconstitutional means. 

The parties engaged in mediation, and on April 3, 2023, the court vacated pending hearings and ordered dismissal without prejudice within 30 days, anticipating a settlement agreement. After agreeing to extend the deadline to June, the parties notified the court on May 15 that they had not reached an agreement and requested that the case be removed from the dismissal calendar. The next day, plaintiffs filed a Motion for Order to Show Cause for why defendants should not be held in civil contempt of the preliminary injunction for the sweep of the Zone the City conducted on May 10, 2023. Plaintiffs alternatively requested a modification of the preliminary injunction. On May 22, the court granted the defendants’ request for an emergency continuance to respond to the plaintiffs’ motion. Given that it was unclear whether defendants planned to move forward with the cleanup on May 24, the court also ordered defendants to not conduct any cleanups in the Zone prior to a hearing on the motion to modify the preliminary injunction. 

On May 23, individual property owners and businesses moved to intervene in this case. The parties noted that they were plaintiffs in an ongoing state court lawsuit against the city of Phoenix, in which they claim the city’s continued maintenance of the Zone constitutes a public nuisance. Brown v. City of Phoenix, No. CV2022-010439 (Maricopa County Super. Ct., filed Aug. 10, 2022). The court granted the motion to intervene on May 25. 

After a hearing on May 26, the court denied the plaintiffs’ Motion for Order to Show Cause and Request for Modification of Preliminary Injunction, and also lifted the order prohibiting defendants from conducting cleanups in the Zone. Soon after, the intervenors filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, arguing that the city’s sweeps of homeless encampments do not rise to an Eighth Amendment violation because they do not punish individuals for their status. The intervenors refuted the Fourth Amendment claim by stating that injunctive relief is “almost always” inappropriate for Fourth Amendment violations, which are better remedied by suppression of evidence or a suit for damages. The motion to dismiss was later joined by the City of Phoenix. 

On October 9th, 2023, the City of Phoenix filed a motion to amend or modify the preliminary injunction. The city cited the impossibility of complying with both the preliminary injunction in this case—which limits how quickly the city can remove unsheltered individuals from the Zone—and the permanent injunction issued by the state court in Brown v. City of Phoenix on September 20. In that case, the Maricopa County Superior Court found that the Zone was a public nuisance and subsequently ordered the City of Phoenix to abate the nuisance by removing tents and drug paraphernalia from the downtown area by November 4, 2023. 

Following a hearing on October 17, the court modified the preliminary injunction to comply with the Ninth Circuit decision in Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, Oregon, 72 F.4th 868 (9th Cir. 2023), which found that it is an Eighth Amendment violation “to criminally punish involuntarily homeless persons for sleeping in public if there are no other public areas or appropriate shelters where those individuals can sleep.” Id. at 877. Accordingly, defendants remained enjoined from enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans or seizing property to the extent requested in their motion to modify the preliminary injunction. 

In January 2024, the court scheduled oral argument on the intervenors’ Motion to Dismiss for March 29, 2024. Also in January, the Supreme Court of the United States granted certiorari in Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, Oregon. The Court will hear oral argument for that case in April. 

On March 29, 2024, the court denied inventors’ Motion to Dismiss as moot and ordered the plaintiffs to amend their complaint within 30 days. On April 29, 2024, the plaintiffs submitted a second amended complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief, adding more individuals as plaintiffs and one additional defendant in her official capacity as Director of the Office of Homeless Solutions (OHS). The second amended complaint detailed the role of OHS (which was created to generate transparency around the homelessness crisis and to implement a system for items taken by the City from those who are unhoused) in working with the Phoenix Police Department to conduct “clean sweeps.” The second amended complaint had an additional claim that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment by imposing excessive fines on individuals for violating the Sleeping Ban, Camping Ban, and Trespassing Bans. 

On May 28, defendants filed a motion to dismiss plaintiffs’ cruel and unusual punishment, excessive force, municipal liability, and state created danger claims. 

On June 24, 2024, the court granted the parties’ stipulation to hold defendants’ Motion to Dismiss in abeyance so plaintiffs could again amend their complaint. 

On June 28, 2024, the Supreme Court of the United States announced its decision in Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, Oregon, which reversed the Ninth Circuit’s holding and held that enforcing bans on camping on public property was not prohibited by the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition against “cruel and unusual punishment.” 

In response to the Supreme Court’s decision in Grants Pass, the plaintiffs filed their third amended complaint on July 12, 2024 to withdraw the claim that the city’s enforcement of the Camping and Sleeping Bans violated the Eighth Amendment. On July 18, 2024, defendants filed a motion to dissolve the preliminary injunction order. The defendants argued that dissolving the preliminary injunction was warranted not only because of the change in law, but also because of changes in fact: “the Zone” had been dismantled and the city adopted policies for the treatment of property inside and outside of “the Zone.” On July 26, the defendants also filed a motion to dismiss the claim for excessive fines and the claim for state-created danger.

The plaintiffs responded to the motion to dissolve the preliminary injunction order on August 1, 2024, conceding that “there may no longer be a basis for the first prohibition on enforcement of the Camping and Sleeping Bans,” but that the other two prohibitions under the injunction were unaffected by Grants Pass because they were rooted in distinct constitutional provisions–the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments, not the Eighth.

As of November 9, 2024, this case is ongoing.

On November 30, 2023, the Fund for Empowerment (FFE) and two individual plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District court for the District of Arizona. The plaintiffs alleged that Phoenixโs policies of criminalizing unsheltered individuals for sleeping outside and destroying their personal property violated the Fourth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights of unsheltered individuals. The court enjoined the city from (1) seizing and destroying any property of unsheltered individuals without providing prior notice, or securely maintaining it for a minimum of 30 days, because the Fourth Amendmentโs Due Process Clause prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures; and (2) enjoined the City from enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans because the Eighth Amendment prohibits the state from imposing criminal penalties for conduct on public property that is an unavoidable consequence of being homeless. After the June 2028 Supreme Court decision in Grants Pass, which held enforcing bans on camping on public property was not prohibited โcruel and unusual punishmentโ under the Eighth Amendment, the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the preliminary injunction order. 

As of November 9, 2024, this case is ongoing.

2  Background 
3  28.  The number of residents experiencing homelessness in Phoenix has nearly

12  The Cityโs Raids 
13  38.  For at least the past two years, the City has engaged in raids it calls โclean 
14  sweepsโ of areas occupied by unsheltered individuals and those experiencing homelessness. 
15  39.  During these raids, unsheltered individuals (including Plaintiffs and those 
16  served by FFE) are roused from sleep by PPD officers in the early morning hours and told 
17  to pack up their blankets, tents, and all their personal belongings. 
18  40.  Some of these raids occur as early as 3:00 AM. 
19  41.  The City directs the PPD and โclean-upโ crews to remove property. 
20  42.  Unsheltered  individuals  (including  Plaintiffs  and  those  served  by  FFE) 
21  typically have just minutes to gather their personal possessions and belongings before the 
22  raid begins. 
23  43.  Because mere minutes are not enough time to gather and relocate possessions 
24  (particularly for people with disabilities), the inevitable result of the Cityโs raids is that 
25  people permanently lose any property they cannot immediately carry away with them.

14  50.  Upon information and belief, the City has used these raids to address the rise

1  Jorge Lopez; Meredith Ryan; Kelly Auer; Committee for Public Counsel Services; and Hampden County Lawyers for 
  Justice. 
 
2  Justice Cypher participated in the deliberation on this case prior to her retirement. 
 
 
3  We acknowledge the amicus briefs submitted by the Institute for Justice; the Exoneration Project; the New England 
  Innocence Project, the Innocence Project, Inc., and the Boston College Innocence Program; the Massachusetts 
Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers; and the Pioneer Valley Project, Citizens for Juvenile Justice, and the 
Criminal Justice Institute at Harvard Law School. 
 
4  The two defense attorney plaintiffs are Meredith Ryan and Kelly Auer. Both serve as bar advocates through HCLJ, 
  and Ryan is a board member and vice-president of HCLJ. The two former defendant plaintiffs are Chris Graham and 
Jorge Lopez, both of whom allege that the district attorneyโs office wrongfully failed to disclose exculpatory material 
during their prosecutions. 
The district attorneyโs office challenges whether the plaintiffs have standing. In her report, the special master found 
that, by virtue of their organizational functions, plaintiffs CPCS and HCLJ have proper representative standing for 
persons (including criminal defendants) whose rights are implicated by the issues underlying the petition. See 
Planned Parenthood League of Mass., Inc. v. Bell, 424 Mass. 573, 578, 677 N.E.2d 204, cert. denied, 522 U.S. 819, 
118 S.Ct. 72, 139 L.Ed.2d 32 (1997). See also Committee for Pub. Counsel Servs. v. Chief Justice of the Trial Court, 
484 Mass. 431, 447, 142 N.E.3d 525, S.C., 484 Mass. 1029, 143 N.E.3d 408 (2020) (organizations representing 
incarcerated individuals had representative standing to challenge their continued incarceration during COVID-19 
pandemic). We agree. Given that CPCS and HCLJ have standing, we decline to reach the unnecessary question of 
standing with regard to the remaining four plaintiffs. 
 
5  Although the special master found that the district attorneyโs office knew of the Kent rebuttalโs existence as of July 
  2, 2021, we do not accept the special masterโs finding as to this date. See New England Oil Ref. Co. v. Canada Mexico 
Oil Co., 274 Mass. 191, 197-198, 174 N.E. 330 (1931) (facts within special masterโs report become indisputable only 
when special masterโs report is confirmed). This error was pointed out by the plaintiffs in their objections to the 
special masterโs factual findings. 
 
6  The special masterโs discussion of other instances where the district attorneyโs office failed to disclose potentially 
  exculpatory findings that an officer was untruthful breaks down into two main categories. In the first category, 
judges discredited the testimony of officers from the department in granting a defendantโs motion to suppress. In 
the second category, officers who had served as prosecution witnesses either testified about their prior dishonest 
conduct or were later indicted for their misconduct. 
19 
 

Graham v. District Attorney for Hampden District, 493 Mass. 348 (2024)   
225 N.E.3d 245 
 
 
7  Following Giglio, the DOJ promulgated a โPolicy Regarding the Disclosure to Prosecutors of Potential Impeachment 
  Information Concerning Law Enforcement Agency Witnessesโ (also known as the โGiglio Policyโ) to better effect 
disclosure. Matter of a Grand Jury Investigation, 485 Mass. at 658, 152 N.E.3d 65. 
 
8  The case of plaintiff Graham offers an example of the exculpatory materials that may be contained within police 
  department internal affairs records. In July 2017, Graham, a Black man, was in an altercation with two white 
off-duty officers. One of the three men pointed a gun during this altercation, but it was unclear who did so, Graham 
or one of the officers. When on-duty officers from the department arrived at the scene, Graham was arrested for, 
among other things, unlawful possession of a loaded firearm. However, during the altercation, an unidentified 911 
caller stated that the Black man involved did not have the gun. After Graham filed a complaint against the arresting 
officers for assault, the internal investigations unit followed up with the 911 caller, who reiterated that the only 
person  with  a  gun  was  a  โwhite  guy.โ  Accordingly,  the  special  master  later  deemed  the  911  call  โclearly 
exculpatory.โ The prosecutor was unaware of the internal investigations unitโs investigation, and defense counsel 
did not obtain the report of that investigation. Therefore, Graham was convicted without knowledge of this call and 
only obtained access to the internal investigation unitโs file through the efforts of his appellate counsel. 
 
9  The case of plaintiff Lopez provides an example of the plaintiffsโ efforts to obtain the documents from the 
  department that underlie the DOJ report. Lopez was a defendant in two criminal cases in Hampden County. After 
the publication of the DOJ report in July 2020, Lopezโs CPCS defense attorney undertook efforts to determine 
whether the officers in Lopezโs case were implicated by the DOJ report. These efforts continued over the course of 
approximately eighteen months. In January 2022, the district attorneyโs office sent over 1,000 pages of files from 
the departmentโs internal investigations unit to Lopezโs defense counsel. In March 2022, while his defense counsel 
was combing through these documents, Lopez pleaded guilty. 
 
1  For instance, a finding that an officer was not wearing his prescription glasses at the time he made an observation. 
 
 
2  In light of the centrality of an investigating police officerโs credibility to effectively prosecuting a crime, an officerโs 
  credibility is often directly linked to his or her capacity to perform essential investigatory functions. When a given 
officerโs credibility is compromised, so too may the broader aims of past and present investigations linked to that 
officer be compromised. Accordingly, police departments, to ensure the integrity of their cases, may elect not to use 
officers with adverse credibility determinations in investigations moving forward. When an adverse credibility 
determination is based on a finding other than that a police officer lied, such intense consequences unjustifiably 
deprive an officer of his or her capacity to continue serving the public honestly, which in turn deprives the public of 
its interest in justice.

22  Plaintiff Fund for the Empowerment (โFFEโ) is an incorporated nonprofit charity 
23  operating in Maricopa County that provides advocacy, programming, and resources to the 
24  countyโs unsheltered population.  Plaintiffs Faith Kearns and Frank Urban are chronically 
25  unsheltered individuals who reside in Maricopa County.  Together, Plaintiffs have filed

27  Department, in her official capacity; Interim Chief of the Phoenix Police Department, 
28  Michael Sullivan, in his official capacity; Entities I-X, political subdivisions of the state of

I.  Legal Standard

When seeking a preliminary injunction, plaintiffs must establish that: (1) they are

7  unchanged after Martin.  Third, the City does not have enough beds to accommodate its 
8  unsheltered residents.  Fourth, Plaintiffs are chronically unsheltered individuals and an 
9  organization that advocates on behalf of unsheltered individuals. 
10  When taken together, these facts suggest that as long as the City enforces the 
11  Camping and Sleeping Bans when the unsheltered outnumber available beds without 
12  inquiring  as  to  whether  individuals  can  practically  obtain  shelter,  unconstitutional 
13  applications are likely.  As mentioned above, there is not enough shelter space for every 
14  unsheltered person to choose whether to sleep or camp outside.  Thus, any enforcement of 
15  the Camping and Sleeping Bans against individuals who practically cannot obtain shelter 
16  effectively criminalizes homelessness.  And where, as is the case here,  โDefendants 
17  operate[] under the impression that they have authority to detain individuals solely because 
18  of their [] status . . . it [is] reasonable for [a] district court to conclude that the Plaintiffs 
19  face[] a real possibility that they would again be stopped or detained and subjected to 
20  unlawful [action] on the basis of their unlawful presence alone.โ  Melendres v. Arpaio, 695 
21  F.3d 990, 1002 (9th Cir. 2012).  Accordingly, like the plaintiffs in Melendres, Plaintiffs in 
22  this case have sufficiently shown that they โface[] irreparable harm in the form of a 
23  deprivation of constitutional rights absent a preliminary injunction.โ  Id.  โPlaintiffs have 
24  shown the likelihood of proving past constitutional violations and there is a potential for 
25  continuing violations,โ in the absence of a requirement that the City be enjoined from 
26  enforcing its ordinance against any persons except those that it can demonstrate are 
27  practically able to obtain housing.  Lavan, 797 F. Supp. 2d at 1019. 
28   
 
- 15 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-02041-GMS   Document 34   Filed 12/16/22   Page 16 of 19
 
 
 
1  2.  Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment Claims  
2  Plaintiffs  also  establish  a  likelihood  of  irreparable  harm  on  their  Fourth  and 
3  Fourteenth Amendment claims with respect to the Cityโs activities outside the scope of the 
4  enhanced cleanup plan.  As noted above, โan alleged constitutional infringement will often 
5  alone constitute irreparable harm.  Associated Gen. Contractors of Cal., Inc. v. Coalition 
6  for Econ. Equity, 950 F.2d 1401, 1412 (9th Cir. 1991).   
7  Here,  the  enhanced  cleanup  plan,  which  Plaintiffs  cannot  demonstrate  is 
8  unconstitutional, only applies in the Zone at scheduled cleanup times.  Because Plaintiffs 
9  demonstrate a likelihood that their property has been taken outside of the Zone, they 
10  establish an alleged constitutional infringement.  Further, Plaintiffs have shown that โthere 
11  is a potential for continuing violationsโ because although the City focuses its efforts on 
12  providing the constitutionally required protections to unsheltered personsโ property within 
13  the Zone during official cleanups, it does not provide any indication that it seeks to provide 
14  those very same protections outside of the cleanups in the Zone.  Lavan, 797 F. Supp. 2d 
15  at 1019 (โPlaintiffs have shown the likelihood of proving past constitutional violations and 
16  there is a potential for continuing violations.โ).  Therefore, if Plaintiffs are unsheltered 
17  outside of the Zone, they remain subject to the Cityโs practice of taking property without 
18  notice and destroying the property without allowing adequate time for the Plaintiffs to 
19  retrieve it.   
20  Lastly, the Cityโs argument that this harm is not irreparable because it can be 
21  recompensed in economic damages ignores the reality of the Plaintiffsโ situations in this 
22  case.  While it may often be the case that taking a tent, an article of clothing, or bedding, 
23  constitutes a chiefly economic injury, in this case, when the City takes those items, it may 
24  be taking everything the person owns.  Additionally, the Plaintiffs have offered evidence 
25  that the Defendants failed to rebut, that the City takes items that are not so easily recovered 
26  in economic damages such as medications, birth certificates, personal mementos, and other 
27  identification documents necessary to obtaining employment and shelter.  Thus, the harm 
28  that Plaintiffs face is irreparable.        
 
- 16 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-02041-GMS   Document 34   Filed 12/16/22   Page 17 of 19
 
 
 
1  C. Balance of the Equities  
2  The balance of hardship also tips in Plaintiffsโ favor on their Eighth Amendment 
3  Claims.  Without a preliminary injunction, Plaintiffs face a continued threat of citation 
4  under  the  Camping  and  Sleeping  Bans.    Legally,  this  threat  is  a  hardship  because 
5  enforcement of the ordinances against individuals that cannot practically obtain shelter 
6  violates their Eighth Amendment rights.  Practically speaking, this threat is also a hardship 
7  because it creates a sense of fear and instability among the Cityโs most vulnerable residents 
8  through no fault of their own.   
9  Admittedly, issuing an injunction will also impose hardships on the Defendants if 
10  they wish to continue easily enforcing the ordinances.  The injunction requires the City to 
11  determine whether individuals are voluntarily homeless before citing them under the 
12  Camping and Sleeping Bans.  Such assessments will be fact-specific and could prove 
13  inherently  difficult  to  administer;  they  might  also  require  the  City  to  increase  its 
14  coordination  with  shelters  or  allocate  more  resources  to  addressing  homelessness.  
15  However, Defendants concede that they are constitutionally obligated to shoulder such 
16  hardships.  (Doc. 18 at 11 (โPrior to any criminal enforcement, officers must investigate 
17  the individualโs circumstances and determine if there is shelter space available.โ).)  Thus 
18  there are no real equities to balance.  If the City wishes to enforce its ordinances, it must 
19  comply with the Constitution in doing so.     
20  The balance of the equities also tips toward the Plaintiffs on their property-related 
21  claims as to the Cityโs activities outside the scope of the enhanced cleanup plan.  In the 
22  absence of an injunction, Plaintiffs face a likelihood that any or all of their belongings 
23  could be seized or destroyed pursuant to the Cityโs practices.  The City, on the other hand, 
24  is minimally harmed by an injunction.  Importantly, it retains authority to engage in the 
25  actions it has a legitimate interest in.  Namely, it โwill still be able to lawfully seize and 
26  detain property, as well as remove hazardous debris and other trash.โ  Lavan, 797 F. Supp. 
27  2d at 1019.  The City will only be prevented from engaging in actions it has no legitimate 
28  interest  in,  that  is,  โunlawfully  seizing  and  destroying  personal  property  that  is  not 
 
- 17 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-02041-GMS   Document 34   Filed 12/16/22   Page 18 of 19
 
 
 
1  abandoned without providing any meaningful notice and opportunity to be heard.โ  Id.  
2  Additionally, to whatever extent a requirement to provide notice and maintain seized 
3  property for 30 days can be seen as a hardship to the City, it has demonstrated the 
4  willingness and ability to establish such a protocol within the Zone.  (Doc. 18-1 at 6.)  The 
5  potential administrative burden on the City associated with expanding those protections 
6  outside the Zone does not outweigh the Plaintiffsโ interests in ensuring their unabandoned 
7  property is not indiscriminately destroyed, whatever city block it may be found on.      
8  D. Public Interest  
9  Finally, the Plaintiffs have shown that a preliminary injunction is in the public 
10  interest with respect to their Eighth Amendment claims.  Although the publicโs interest in 
11  enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans is legitimate, this interest is not sufficient to 
12  overcome the fact that the Constitution protects unsheltered individuals from statutes that 
13  โeffectively punish them for something for which they may not be convicted under the 
14  [E]ighth [A]mendmentโsleeping, eating and other innocent conduct.โ  Martin, 920 F.3d 
15  at 617.  Indeed, โit is always in the public interest to prevent the violation of a partyโs 
16  constitutional  rights,โ  especially  where  a  party  is  among  โthose  most  in  need  of 
17  [constitutional] protections.โ Melendres, 695 F.3d at 1002; Cobine v. City of Eureka 
18  (Cobine II), No. C 16-02239 JSW, 2016 WL 1730084, at *7 (N.D. Cal. May 2, 2016).   
19  Further, entering a narrow injunction preventing unlawful seizures and destruction 
20  of property is also in the public interest.  The injunction does not prevent the City from 
21  moving forward with its facially constitutional enhanced cleanups of the Zone or lawfully 
22  engaging in its regular public health and safety activities.  Therefore, the public is not 
23  harmed by an injunction requiring basic constitutional protections for unsheltered personsโ 
24  property.   
25  CONCLUSION    
26  Accordingly, all four Winter factors tilt in Plaintiffsโ favor on their claims, except 
27  the likelihood of success on their challenge to the constitutionality of the Cityโs enhanced 
28  cleanup plan within the Zone.  Thus,  
 
- 18 - 

 
Case 2:22-cv-02041-GMS   Document 34   Filed 12/16/22   Page 19 of 19
 
 
 
1  IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED  that the Motion for Preliminary Injunction 
2  (Doc. 2) is GRANTED in part and DENIED in part.  
3  IT  IS  FURTHER  ORDERED that  the  City,  its  agents  and  employees,  are 
4  preliminarily enjoined from doing any of the following: 
5  1.  Enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans against individuals who practically 
6  cannot obtain shelter as long as there are more unsheltered individuals in Phoenix 
7  than there are shelter beds available;  
8  2.  Seizing  any  property  of  the  unsheltered  without  providing  prior  notice  at  the 
9  propertyโs location that the property will be seized, unless the agent or employee 
10  has  an  objectively  reasonable  belief  that  it  is  (a)  abandoned,  (b)  presents  an 
11  immediate  threat  to  public  health  or  safety,  or  (c)  is  evidence  of  a  crime  or 
12  contraband; and 
13  3.  Absent an immediate threat to public health or safety, destroying said property 
14  without maintaining it in a secure location for a period of less than 30 days. 
15  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that if property is seized pursuant to a belief that it 
16  was abandoned or after the City provides notice that it intends to seize the property, the 
17  City, its agents and employees, are further required to provide a notice at the location from 
18  which the property was seized, calculated to be readily seen by any owner of the property, 
19  describing how and where to retrieve the property and the deadline for retrieving it.  
20    Dated this 16th day of December, 2022.

1  GENERAL FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
2  Background 
3  27.  The number of residents experiencing homelessness in Phoenix has nearly 
4  doubled  since  2010  according  to  Point-in-Time  (โPITโ)  counts  commissioned  by  the 
5  Maricopa Association of Governments (โMAGโ).13 
6  28.  This increase directly relates to the Cityโs lack of affordable housing for 
7  residents that has only been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic.14 
8  29.  Without  an  adequate  supply  of  affordable  housing,  people  can  become 
9  unsheltered after disruptions in household income caused by job loss, medical bankruptcy, 
10  mental illness, divorce, or domestic violence. 
11  30.  In 2010, about 1,750 unsheltered individuals were reported as experiencing

16     After  reviewing  the  Plaintiffsโ  Motion  for  Preliminary  Injunction  (Doc.  2), 
17  associated filings and affidavits, and the partiesโ arguments during the Preliminary Hearing 
18  on December 14, 2022, Plaintiffsโ motion is granted in part and denied in part.  The Court 
19  issues this abbreviated order in light of the Defendant Cityโs upcoming enhanced cleaning, 
20  which is scheduled to take place on Friday, December 16, 2022.  An order setting forth the 
21  Courtโs analysis of the partiesโ arguments and explaining the preliminary injunction below 
22  more fully will promptly issue, hereafter.  Nevertheless, though Plaintiffโs motion is 
23  granted in part, nothing in this Order or the forthcoming Order precludes the City from 
24  conducting its enhanced cleanup plans in the area referred to in the motions as โthe Zoneโ 
25  on December 16, 2022, pursuant to the Cityโs procedures and briefings as represented to 
26  the Court in this case.   
27    Accordingly, 
28  IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that Plaintiffsโ Motion for Preliminary Injunction 
 

 
Case 2:22-cv-02041-GMS   Document 32   Filed 12/15/22   Page 2 of 2
 
 
 
1  (Doc. 2) is granted in part and denied in part. 
2  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED granting that the City, its agents and employees, are 
3  preliminarily enjoined from doing any of the following: 
4  1.  Enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans against individuals who practically 
5  cannot obtain shelter as long as there are more unsheltered individuals in Phoenix 
6  than there are shelter beds available;  
7  2.  Seizing  any  property  of  the  unsheltered  without  providing  prior  notice  at  the 
8  propertyโs location that the property will be seized, unless the agent or employee 
9  has  an  objectively  reasonable  belief  that  it  is  (a)  abandoned,  (b)  presents  an 
10  immediate  threat  to  public  health  or  safety,  or  (c)  is  evidence  of  a  crime  or 
11  contraband; and 
12  3.  Absent an immediate threat to public health or safety, destroying said property 
13  without maintaining it in a secure location for a period of less than 30 days. 
14  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that if property is seized pursuant to a belief that it 
15  was abandoned or after the City provides notice that it intends to seize the property, the 
16  City, its agents and employees, are further required to provide a notice at the location from 
17  which the property was seized, calculated to be readily seen by any owner of the property, 
18  describing how and where to retrieve the property and the deadline for retrieving it. 
19  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Motion for Leave to File amicus brief by

16  On October 17, 2023, an expedited Telephonic Status Conference was held on 
17  Defendantsโ Motion to Modify the Preliminary Injunction and Motion for Expedited 
18  Consideration and Emergency Status Conference (Doc. 109).   
19  The Courtโs December 16, 2022 Order preliminarily enjoined the City of Phoenix 
20  and its agents and employees from the following: 
21  1.  Enforcing the Camping and Sleeping Bans against individuals who 
22  practically cannot obtain shelter as long as there are more unsheltered 
23  individuals in Phoenix than there are shelter beds available; 
24  2.  Seizing any property of the unsheltered without providing prior notice 
25  at the propertyโs location that the property will be seized, unless the 
26  agent or employee  has an objectively reasonable belief that it  is 
27  (a) abandoned, (b) presents an immediate threat to public health or 
28  safety, or (c) is evidence of a crime or contraband; and

1  3.  Absent an immediate threat to public health or safety, destroying said 
2  property without maintaining it in a secure location for a period of less 
3  than 30 days. 
4  (Doc. 34 at 19.) 
5  Very recently, the Ninth Circuitโs amended decision, Johnson v. City of Grants 
6  Pass,  72  F.4th  868  (9th  Cir.  2023),  clarified  the  beds-versus-population  formula 
7  established in Martin on which the Court relied on in entering the preliminary injunction.  
8  See Martin v. City of Boise, 920 F.3d 584, 617 (9th Cir. 2019) (โWe hold only that โso long 
9  as there is a greater number of homeless individuals in [a jurisdiction] than the number of 
10  available beds [in shelters],โ the jurisdiction cannot prosecute homeless individuals for 
11  โinvoluntarily sitting,  lying, and sleeping in public.โโ) (quoting  Jones v. City of  Los 
12  Angeles, 444 F.3d 1118, 1138 (9th Cir. 2006), vacated, 505 F.3d 1006 (9th Cir. 2007)) 
13  (alteration in original); see also Johnson v. City of Grants Pass, 50 F.4th 787, 795 (9th Cir. 
14  2022), superseded, 72 F.4th 868 (9th Cir. 2023) (quoting the Martin formula); (Doc. 34 at 
15  6).  The Ninth Circuitโs amended decision replaced the formula expressed in Martin with 
16  the following: โPursuant to Martin, it is an Eighth Amendment violation to criminally 
17  punish involuntarily homeless persons for sleeping in public if there are no other public 
18  areas or appropriate shelters where those individuals can sleep.โ  Johnson v. City of Grants 
19  Pass, 72 F.4th 868, 877 (9th Cir. 2023). In footnote 33 of the amended decision, the Ninth 
20  Circuit declined to โdecide whether alternate outdoor space would be sufficient under 
21  Martinโ because โthe City ha[d] not established any realistically available place within the 
22  jurisdiction for involuntarily homeless individuals to sleep.โ  Johnson, 72 F.4th at 894 n.33.   
23  The portions of the Courtโs Order that enjoins the City from violating the Fourth 
24  and Fourteenth Amendments remains the same.  See (Doc. 34 at 7โ14, 19); see also 
25  Johnson, 72 F.4th at 881(finding โit is unnecessary to decide [the p]laintiffsโ procedural 
26  due process claimโ). 
27  IT IS HEREBY ORDERED that the Defendantsโ Motion to Modify Preliminary 
28  Injunction (Doc. 109) is GRANTED in part and DENIED in part.  It is granted in part

4  homeless persons for sleeping in public if there are no other public
